title: From Courtside to Code: A Real Guide to Getting Started in Sports Analytics
description: A deep dive into using Python, Pandas, and Matplotlib to analyze NBA efficiency. Learn how to transform raw JSON data into actionable insights.
content:
If you spend as much time watching NBA highlights as I do, you've probably realized that the game has fundamentally shifted. It isn't just about who can hit the most contested jumpers or who has the highest vertical anymore. Sports analytics has become the primary lens through which the modern game is understood, offering a way to cut through the noise of traditional box scores. Teams now leverage granular data to optimize draft boards, refine defensive rotations, and even dictate load management schedules for star athletes.

For many fans, the word 'analytics' feels like a dry math lecture. But you don't need a PhD to start building your own tools. I'm walking through a program I've been developing that transforms raw NBA data into actionable insights you can use to manage a fantasy team or win a circular debate about player value.

Setting Up Your Environment

Before we can look at any stats, we need to get your computer ready to handle the data. We're using Python because it is the industry standard for data science, offering a massive ecosystem of libraries specifically designed for statistical modeling. To replicate this setup, you'll need three core libraries:

Pandas: The 'Excel for Python,' used to handle complex data tables known as DataFrames.
Matplotlib: A comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations.
adjustText: A small but vital tool that prevents text labels from overlapping on your graphs.

You can install these via your terminal with a single command: pip install pandas matplotlib adjustText.

The Data: Our Raw Material

For this project, we are working with a JSON file called 2025-26.NBA.Roster.json. In the world of data, JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight format used to store and transport data. Think of it as a giant, nested tree containing every player's physical attributes and every statistical category they've touched.

Our objective is to parse this massive, unstructured file and filter it down to the 2025 regular season.

Step 1: Loading and Cleaning the Data

Data cleaning is 80% of an analyst's job. We start by importing our libraries and defining a function to load the JSON file.

python
import json
import pandas as pd

def load_nba_data(file_path, season=2025):
    with open(file_path, 'r') as f:
        data = json.load(f)

Inside this function, we loop through every player and extract specific metrics. We calculate Total Rebounds by adding Offensive (orb) and Defensive (drb) rebounds, and we filter specifically for regular-season games to ensure our averages aren't skewed by smaller sample sizes.

python
    rows = []
    for p in data['players']:
        name = p.get('name') or f"{p.get('firstName', '')} {p.get('lastName', '')}".strip()
        
        for s in p.get('stats', []):
            if s['season'] == season and not s['playoffs']:
                rows.append({
                    'Name': name,
                    'Points': s['pts'],
                    'Assists': s['ast'],
                    'Rebounds': s['orb'] + s['drb'],
                    'Minutes': s['min'],
                    'Games': s['gp']
                })
    return pd.DataFrame(rows)

Step 2: Visualizing Efficiency

Now that we have a clean DataFrame, we need to make it look good. I wrote a second function, plot_nba_stats, to calculate Per Game metrics. Total points are often a 'survival' statâ€”they tell you who played the most games. Points Per Game (PPG) tells you who was the most productive when they actually stepped on the court.

python
def plot_nba_stats(df, stat_name):
    per_game_col = f"{stat_name} Per Game"
    df[per_game_col] = df[stat_name] / df['Games']
    
    top_10 = df.sort_values(by=per_game_col, ascending=False).head(10)

Interpreting the Results

When you run this program, the real insight comes from the Scatter Plot comparing Minutes Played against your chosen stat.

Top-Left Quadrant: High production in low minutes. These are your 'efficiency darlings' who likely deserve a larger role.
Bottom-Right Quadrant: High minutes with low production. These players may be 'floor spacers' or are significantly underperforming their workload.

The Future: Beyond the Box Score

This is just the tip of the iceberg. As an Economics student, I'm particularly interested in how we can apply financial modeling to these numbers. Once you're comfortable with Pandas, you can move toward Advanced Metrics like True Shooting Percentage (TS%) or Usage Rate.

The numbers don't have a favorite team. By writing just a few lines of Python, you move from being a spectator to an analyst. Happy hunting.

title: The NFC East: A Division in Transition
description: A deep dive into the coaching carousel and competitive landscape of the NFC East heading into 2026, featuring insights on the Eagles, Commanders, Cowboys, and Giants.
content:
Thank you to Ameya Idate for writing this article.

As the NFL regular season winds down, a strange silence has settled over the playoff bracket. For the first time since 2017, the postseason will not feature Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, or Joe Burrow. While most of the attention is on the Lombardi Trophy hunt, one division in particular stands out as a focal point for change: the NFC East.

The Philadelphia Eagles
They finished 11-6, but they are grappling with a sudden identity crisis. After losing offensive coordinator Kellen Moore to Kevin Patullo, the unit has regressed. Despite having Saquon Barkley and the elite receiving duo of A.J. Brown and DeVonta Smith, the run game essentially collapsed, losing nearly 40 percent of its rushing yardage per game.

The Washington Commanders
Coming off a disappointing 5-12 season, the organization is hitting the reset button. While head coach Dan Quinn remains, the team is parting ways with offensive coordinator Kliff Kingsbury and defensive coordinator Joe Witt Jr. This team is no longer just looking to compete; they are looking to prove they weren't one-hit wonders with Jayden Daniels.

The Dallas Cowboys
The Cowboys continue to be the league's mark of mediocrity, finishing 7-9-1. Statistically, Dallas has one of the best offenses, ranking 1st in yards per game with Dak Prescott and George Pickens. However, the defense lacked stability, leading to the firing of defensive coordinator Matt Eberflus.

The New York Giants
New York moved on from head coach Brian Daboll midseason. After losing Malik Nabers and Cam Skattebo to injuries, the team fell off. However, rookie quarterback Jaxon Dart exceeded all expectations, and Abdul Carter emerged as a promising edge rusher. With a top 5 draft pick on the way, the pieces are there for a quick turnaround.

title: The Impact of Analytics: Beyond the Box Score
description: An exploration of why raw scoring isn't everything in the NBA. Comparing the offensive gravity of stars like Zach LaVine to the 'glue' impact of role players.
content:
Imagine you are an NBA general manager and you have to choose between two players. Player A averages 20 points; Player B averages 10 points. If you look at the box score, Player A is the one getting the headlines. But if you look at the win column, everything flips.

The Case for Efficiency
In the 2023 season, Zach LaVine often saw the Bulls play better while he was on the bench, carrying a negative 18.8 On/Off rating. Meanwhile, Alex Caruso was the heartbeat of the team, maintaining a positive net rating with almost every teammate he shared the floor with.

The Engine Problem
The 2021 Brooklyn Nets are the ultimate cautionary tale. Having Kevin Durant, James Harden, and Kyrie Irving seemed like a cheat code. The problem is that a basketball game only has one ball. When you have three players who all need a 30 percent usage rate, you reach diminishing returns.

The Glue Guys
Compare the Nets to the 2021 Milwaukee Bucks. They replaced Eric Bledsoe with Jrue Holiday. While Holiday's raw scoring numbers weren't always massive, his defensive presence was suffocating. He won possession after possession on the margins. Analytics has taught us that surrounding a superstar like Giannis with hyper-efficient connectors is more valuable than adding a second high-volume, low-defense scorer.

title: The First Post: Setting Up the Site
description: A quick look at the process of building this minimalist, weather-reactive portfolio using React and Tailwind.
content: Welcome to my new personal site. This project was born out of a desire for a clean, typography-focused space to share thoughts on sports, data, and media. Built with React and Tailwind CSS, it features a dynamic weather system and three distinct themes (Light, Dark, and Sunset). I'll be using this space to document my projects and share my findings in the world of sports analytics.
